articles.headline: New Star Wars Plan: Pentagon Rushes to Counter Threats in Orbit
articles.snippet: Citing rapid advances by China and Russia, the United States is building an extensive capacity to fight battles in space.
articles.abstract: Citing rapid advances by China and Russia, the United States is building an extensive capacity to fight battles in space.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon is rushing to expand its capacity to wage war in space, convinced that rapid advances by China and Russia in space-based operations pose a growing threat to U.S. troops and other military assets on the ground and American satellites in orbit.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Take My Wife, Please: For Political Damage Control, Just Blame Your Spouse
articles.snippet: When Justice Samuel Alito and Senator Bob Menendez landed in hot water, they looked for a scapegoat close to home. Inside their homes, in fact.
articles.abstract: When Justice Samuel Alito and Senator Bob Menendez landed in hot water, they looked for a scapegoat close to home. Inside their homes, in fact.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a tale as old as Adam and Eve: A husband, faced with accusations of misconduct, blames the wife.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Mercedes Workers in Alabama Reject Union
articles.snippet: The election, fiercely opposed by the state’s political leaders, was seen as a test of the United Automobile Workers’ ability to unionize factories in the South.
articles.abstract: The election, fiercely opposed by the state’s political leaders, was seen as a test of the United Automobile Workers’ ability to unionize factories in the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers at two Mercedes-Benz factories near Tuscaloosa, Ala., voted on Friday against allowing the United Automobile Workers to represent them, a stunning blow to the union’s campaign to gain ground in the South, where it has traditionally been weak.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Mexico City Has Long Thirsted for Water. The Crisis Is Worsening.
articles.snippet: A system of dams and canals may soon be unable to provide water to one of the world’s largest cities, a confluence of unchecked growth, crumbling infrastructure and a changing climate.
articles.abstract: A system of dams and canals may soon be unable to provide water to one of the world’s largest cities, a confluence of unchecked growth, crumbling infrastructure and a changing climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: A collision of climate change, urban sprawl and poor infrastructure has pushed Mexico City to the brink of a profound water crisis.
articles.byline: By James Wagner, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Somini Sengupta and César Rodríguez

articles.headline: What’s BlackRock Without Larry Fink? Shareholders Fret About Future.
articles.snippet: Investors in the world’s biggest asset manager are asking how much more room it has to grow and who will drive that growth once its chief executive retires.
articles.abstract: Investors in the world’s biggest asset manager are asking how much more room it has to grow and who will drive that growth once its chief executive retires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Laurence D. Fink built BlackRock into the world’s largest asset manager with a steely grip, a thick skin and a cleareyed vision of what the company could become.
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell

articles.headline: A Loss at Mercedes-Benz Slows U.A.W.’s Southern Campaign
articles.snippet: After Mercedes workers voted against joining the United Automobile Workers, the union will have less momentum as it campaigns to organize Southern factories.
articles.abstract: After Mercedes workers voted against joining the United Automobile Workers, the union will have less momentum as it campaigns to organize Southern factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: After suffering a setback at two Mercedes-Benz plants in Alabama on Friday, the United Automobile Workers union’s efforts to organize other auto factories in the South are likely to slow and could struggle to make headway.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Israel’s Wartime Government Frays as Frustration with Netanyahu Grows
articles.snippet: Benny Gantz, a centrist member of leadership, presented the prime minister with an ultimatum that demanded a plan for the future of Israel’s war.
articles.abstract: Benny Gantz, a centrist member of leadership, presented the prime minister with an ultimatum that demanded a plan for the future of Israel’s war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Benny Gantz, a centrist member of Israel’s war cabinet, presented Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with an ultimatum on Saturday, saying he would leave the government if it did not soon develop a plan for the future of the war in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Ephrat Livni and Kayla Guo

articles.headline: Are Those Mimes Spying on Us? In Pakistan, It’s Not a Strange Question.
articles.snippet: Pakistanis suspect the national intelligence agencies of being behind practically everything — even street performers working for tips in Islamabad.
articles.abstract: Pakistanis suspect the national intelligence agencies of being behind practically everything — even street performers working for tips in Islamabad.
articles.lead_paragraph: The street performers first appeared a few years ago along busy intersections of Islamabad. Coated head to toe in eye-catching gold paint, they stood perfectly still, leaning on glimmering canes and tipping their top hats open. Some cracked a smile or offered a slow nod when they earned tips from passers-by.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum

articles.headline: Jürgen Klopp and Liverpool, a Love Affair in Street Art and Silverware
articles.snippet: A coach’s soccer legacy is often reduced to titles and trophies. In Liverpool, a beloved manager will endure in murals, music and shared memories.
articles.abstract: A coach’s soccer legacy is often reduced to titles and trophies. In Liverpool, a beloved manager will endure in murals, music and shared memories.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jürgen Klopp’s week had been full of goodbyes. Liverpool’s now former manager had bade farewell to the club’s staff at Anfield, the stadium that had sung his name and thrilled at his team for the last nine years, on Tuesday. A couple of days later, he and his players shared one last barbecue at Liverpool’s training facility.
articles.byline: By Rory Smith

articles.headline: ‘We’ll See You at Your House’: How Fear and Menace Are Transforming Politics
articles.snippet: Public officials from Congress to City Hall are now regularly subjected to threats of violence. It’s changing how they do their jobs.
articles.abstract: Public officials from Congress to City Hall are now regularly subjected to threats of violence. It’s changing how they do their jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Friday last month, Jamie Raskin, a Democratic congressman from Maryland, spent a chunk of his day in court securing a protective order.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Ken Bensinger and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Renting Forever and Trying to Create a Strong Financial Future
articles.snippet: Either by choice or because they are priced out of the market, many people plan to never stop renting. Building wealth without home equity requires a different mind-set.
articles.abstract: Either by choice or because they are priced out of the market, many people plan to never stop renting. Building wealth without home equity requires a different mind-set.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moving back and forth between Tennessee and Alaska, Michael Rogers and his wife, Christy, have twice been stuck simultaneously paying a mortgage and rent. Once, in 2006, the situation dragged on for eight months, finally ending when they sold their house in Tennessee for $20,000 below what they’d paid for it.
articles.byline: By Paulette Perhach

articles.headline: The High-Class Problem That Comes With Home Equity
articles.snippet: You may feel richer as you pay your mortgage down and home values go up. Using that equity is another matter entirely.
articles.abstract: You may feel richer as you pay your mortgage down and home values go up. Using that equity is another matter entirely.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lot of money is tied up in people’s homes. Those who need to tap it most, however, may have the hardest time doing so.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Biden Draws on Themes of Manhood and Faith at Morehouse Commencement
articles.snippet: The president’s appearance at the historically Black college in Atlanta drew some respectful but noticeable protest over U.S. support for Israel’s war in Gaza.
articles.abstract: The president’s appearance at the historically Black college in Atlanta drew some respectful but noticeable protest over U.S. support for Israel’s war in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden invoked scripture and lessons from his own tragic past on Sunday in a commencement address to hundreds of young Black men at Morehouse College, saying he believes there are “extremist forces aligned against the meaning and message” of the prestigious institution.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Maya King

articles.headline: A Boxing Victory Offers Hope to War-Weary Ukrainians
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Usyk became the world’s undisputed heavyweight champion on Sunday. The victory has lifted morale in a country struggling to contain Russian advances on the battlefield.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Usyk became the world’s undisputed heavyweight champion on Sunday. The victory has lifted morale in a country struggling to contain Russian advances on the battlefield.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many Ukrainians were up in the early hours of Sunday morning, for once not to seek shelter from incoming Russian missiles, but to celebrate the Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Usyk becoming the world’s undisputed heavyweight champion.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut, Maria Varenikova and Nataliia Novosolova

articles.headline: Helicopter Carrying Iran’s President Has Crashed, State Media Reports
articles.snippet: Rescuers are trying to locate the helicopter on which President Ebrahim Raisi and Foreign Minister Hossein Amir Abdollahian were traveling, state media reported. Their status is unknown.
articles.abstract: Rescuers are trying to locate the helicopter on which President Ebrahim Raisi and Foreign Minister Hossein Amir Abdollahian were traveling, state media reported. Their status is unknown.
articles.lead_paragraph: A helicopter carrying President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran and his foreign minister crashed on Sunday in the country’s mountainous northwest, according to state media, deepening the turmoil that has gripped the nation on both the international and domestic fronts in recent months.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Chinese Firms Face Authoritarianism at Home and Hostility Abroad
articles.snippet: The experience of TikTok’s owner, ByteDance, in Beijing and Washington shows how much the ground has shifted for China’s entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: The experience of TikTok’s owner, ByteDance, in Beijing and Washington shows how much the ground has shifted for China’s entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: One April afternoon in 2018, Zhang Yiming, the founder of the Beijing-based online media company ByteDance, got a notice from Chinese regulators to shut down an app where people shared jokes and silly videos.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan

articles.headline: Europe Wants to Build a Stronger Defense Industry, but Can’t Decide How
articles.snippet: Conflicting political visions, competitive jockeying and American dominance stand in the way of a more coordinated and efficient military machine.
articles.abstract: Conflicting political visions, competitive jockeying and American dominance stand in the way of a more coordinated and efficient military machine.
articles.lead_paragraph: France and Germany’s recent agreement to develop a new multibillion-dollar battlefield tank together was immediately hailed by the German defense minister, Boris Pistorius, as a “breakthrough” achievement.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: This ‘Russian Woman’ Loves China. Too Bad She’s a Deepfake.
articles.snippet: A.I.-manipulated videos on Chinese sites use young, supposedly Russian women to promote China-Russia ties, stoke patriotism — and make money.
articles.abstract: A.I.-manipulated videos on Chinese sites use young, supposedly Russian women to promote China-Russia ties, stoke patriotism — and make money.
articles.lead_paragraph: The woman declares, in Mandarin inflected with a slight accent, that Chinese men should marry “us Russian women.” In other videos on the Chinese short video platform Douyin, she describes how much she loves Chinese food, and hawks salt and soap from her country. “Russian people don’t trick Chinese people,” she promises.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao

articles.headline: How Gun Violence Spread Across One American City
articles.snippet: Columbus, Ohio, had only about 100 homicides a year. Then came a pandemic surge. With more guns and looser laws, can the city find its way back to the old normal?
articles.abstract: Columbus, Ohio, had only about 100 homicides a year. Then came a pandemic surge. With more guns and looser laws, can the city find its way back to the old normal?
articles.lead_paragraph: The sequence of events that led to the killing of Jason Keys was so confounding that friends and family did not quite believe it until they saw the video evidence played in court.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan, Robert Gebeloff and Sylvia Jarrus

articles.headline: Senate Inquiry Finds BMW Imported Cars Tied to Forced Labor in China
articles.snippet: The report also found that Jaguar Land Rover and Volkswagen bought parts from a supplier the U.S. government had singled out for its practices in Xinjiang.
articles.abstract: The report also found that Jaguar Land Rover and Volkswagen bought parts from a supplier the U.S. government had singled out for its practices in Xinjiang.
articles.lead_paragraph: A congressional investigation found that BMW, Jaguar Land Rover and Volkswagen purchased parts that originated from a Chinese supplier flagged by the United States for participating in forced labor programs in Xinjiang, a far western region of China where the local population is subject to mass surveillance and detentions.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: International Criminal Court Prosecutor Requests Warrants for Netanyahu and Hamas Leaders
articles.snippet: While the request must be approved by the court’s judges, the announcement is a harsh rebuke of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his war strategy in Gaza.
articles.abstract: While the request must be approved by the court’s judges, the announcement is a harsh rebuke of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his war strategy in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief prosecutor at the world’s top criminal court on Monday announced that he was seeking arrest warrants for the leaders of both Israel and Hamas on charges of crimes against humanity, a strong rebuke that equated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with his Hamas counterpart, Yahya Sinwar, and compounded the growing international alarm at Israel’s conduct in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

articles.headline: Russia’s War Machine Revs Up as the West’s Plan to Cap Oil Revenues Sputters
articles.snippet: Russia has largely evaded attempts by the U.S. and Europe to keep it from profiting from its energy exports.
articles.abstract: Russia has largely evaded attempts by the U.S. and Europe to keep it from profiting from its energy exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and its allies in the Group of 7 nations set two goals in 2022 when they enacted a novel plan to cap the price of Russian oil: restrict Moscow’s ability to profit from its energy exports while allowing its oil to continue flowing on international markets to prevent a global price shock.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport
